title: Srimad Bhagavatam | HG Madhu Pandit Dasa | SB 3.20.37 | 23-02-2016
speaker: HG Madhu Pandit Dasa

segments.key_quote: Asuras are described as Mudadhya, meaning they are captivated by ignorance.
segments.summary: The speaker explains that Asuras are captivated by ignorance and are foolish because they are attracted to the illusory attractions of the material world.
segments.transcript: were completely floored by the beautiful woman, and after that they simply seized her, grabbed her, they embraced her. So Prabhupada is explaining here that the Asuras are described as Mudadhya, meaning they are captivated by ignorance. So only those who are captivated by the mode of ignorance and passion will subject themselves to this force of false attraction, illusory attraction in this material world, and they are considered to be Mudadhya, means not very intelligent, or they are foolish. One who knows things as they are, then one would not run after the things in this material world.

segments.key_quote: One gives experience of gold, the other one is real gold and real gold also gives experience of gold but it has also got the value of gold that is a difference.
segments.summary: Using the analogy of real gold versus plated gold, the speaker explains the difference between experiential truth and existential truth, highlighting that true value lies in something being both experientially and existentially true.
segments.transcript: In other words, if you really want to buy gold, then you have to, unless you get real gold, you are cheated. Something will be gold-like, plated gold. It will look bad, but look like gold for the senses. It looks like gold. There's no difference between the rolled gold and the plated gold and real gold. There's no difference for the senses, but for the value there will be a difference. One has no value, the other has got very high value comparatively, and one has no value. So one gives experience of gold, the other one is real gold, and real gold also gives experience of gold, but it has also got the value of gold. That is the difference. One is experientially true, the other one is experientially true and existentially true. In existence also it is real gold.

segments.key_quote: To establish the existential truth of something, any amount of experiences with the senses will not determine that truth. One has to go beyond the senses and go to the intelligence.
segments.summary: The speaker asserts that sensory experience alone cannot establish existential truth; one must go beyond the senses to intelligence and spiritual knowledge (Guru, Sadhu, and Shastra).
segments.transcript: So any sense perception, anything that we see, if it is only true experientially, it is not necessary that it is truth. Truth has to be established independently on the basis of experience. For instance, you watch a movie. Once you go into the movie world, it's a real experience. It is a real experience. The experience is as real as real life experience, no difference. But is that true existentially true? No. Experientially true, but existentially false. Now if you want to analyze, you want to, whether that movie is existentially true or experientially, I am seeing it is true. Now I want to find out whether it is existentially true. So you analyze the movie more and more. The movie plot, you go into the movie plot. Okay, in the movie plot, this character, that character, you go on analyzing. Will you ever come out of the movie? No. In other words, to establish the existential truth of something, any amount of experiences with the senses will not determine that truth. One has to go beyond the senses and go to the intelligence. And intelligence, the source of that intelligence should be independent of that movie, because intelligence is not coming from the movie. And that is the third source. It is not coming from the movie, and that is spiritual knowledge.

segments.key_quote: There is only way to establish whether an experience is existentially true or not, is by a third source, that is Shastra.
segments.summary: The speaker emphasizes that Shastra is the only reliable source for determining whether an experience is existentially true, as our senses are prone to illusion.
segments.transcript: Guru, Sadhu and Shastra. The spiritual knowledge, even though it is available in ordinary, material paper, material ink. It is available here. PRESENT TRUTH. But that is not real spiritual knowledge. It is manifesting like this, like any other ordinary book. But the vibration, the sound that is generated, the sound that it represents, this transcendental knowledge, that is the independent source, independent of our sensual perceptions. Our sensual perceptions can make mistakes, commit tendencies for illusion, cheating, all these things. So there is no question of establishing whether something is illusion or whether something is true by your senses, you cannot. There is only way to establish whether an experience is existentially true or not, is by a third source, that is Shastra.

segments.key_quote: Soul is not directly feeling anything in this world.
segments.summary: The speaker explains that those seeking ultimate truth understand that experiences are generated by the material body, mind, and intelligence, while the soul merely observes, identifying with the feelings of the 'yantra' (machine).
segments.transcript: That is the verdict of the scriptures. But ultimately, those who want to go out of this material world, those who want ultimate truth, absolute truth, they understand that all these things are created by this body, which is body, mind and intelligence, which is a material yantra. And all experiences are generated out of this yantra. And the soul is only a kshetrajna. Soul is not feeling anything. Soul is feeling the feeling. Soul is not directly feeling anything in this world. When you feel angry with someone, you are not angry. Your kshetra is generating that anger and you are identifying with that anger. It is not direct feeling. The feeling of the yantra, you are identifying. Thinking of the yantra, you are identifying. Impulses of the yantra, you are misunderstanding to be your decision, your impulses. prakṛtaya kriyamānāni guṇaya karmāni sarvaśa āhankāraṁ itimam āhankāraṁ kartāḥ itimanyate So, only by a false ego, one thinks one is doing, one is, you know, it is my feeling, it is my, I am angry, etc., etc. I am having pleasure, all these things.

segments.key_quote: In the same way, in this material world, maya is expert, expert like a jeweler who cheats. She is expert. Her job is to duplicate the gold of the spiritual world here.
segments.summary: The speaker compares Maya to a jeweler who expertly duplicates gold, creating illusions of thinking, feeling, and willing, just as the soul does, to deceive people in the material world.
segments.transcript: So, but the nature of the soul is to feel, to think, feel and will. Body cannot think, feel and will. segments.key_quote: We create in our mind illusion. And that mannequin, that fiberglass doll is just a trigger in your mind.
segments.summary: Using the analogy of a mannequin in a saree shop, the speaker explains how Maya duplicates names, forms, and qualities, triggering desires and illusions in our minds, leading us to paste our identity onto the body.
segments.transcript: We don't think. Just like in the saree shop outside you have mannequins. Fiberglass model of women and they wear saree. They decorate that mannequin with saree. Plastic. Those who have desire, they will see that model wearing the saree. They will project their own face there, how nice I will be there. And then they will enter the saree shop. You don't even see the person. The person is travelling in the body. But you paste, we paste the identity of the person onto the body.

segments.key_quote: Krishna consciousness is meant to take us out of this bodily concept of life and come into spiritual concept of life.
segments.summary: The speaker explains that we live in a bodily concept of life, residing in the subtle body, and Krishna consciousness aims to shift us to a spiritual concept of life, realizing ourselves as spirit souls with the potential for a sacchidananda body.

Each of our limbs are under our control, so it's me, it is me. I cannot control your hand, so I don't think that hand is mine. I can control my hand, so I think this is me. Hand, leg, so finally you think this body is me. And then you create a bodily concept of life. Body is different, bodily concept is different. Bodily concept is where? It is in the subtle body. So actually we are living in bodily concept of life. We are not living in the body. If you are living in the body then you become immediately conscious. Oh, what is this? This is a yantra. But you live in the bodily concept of life. So Krishna consciousness is meant to take us out of this bodily concept of life and come into spiritual concept of life. I am spirit soul. To start with. Then I am sacchidananda body. That one gets a sacchidananda body.
